{{Ottoman Turkish name|Namık Kemal}} {{Infobox writer | name = Namık Kemal | image = Kemalbey.jpg | image_size= |caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1840|12|21|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Tekirdağ]], [[Ottoman Empire]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1888|12|2|1840|12|21|df=y}} | death_place = [[Chios]], [[Ottoman Empire]] | resting_place = [[Bolayır]], [[Gelibolu]] | occupation = [[Poet]], [[novelist]], [[journalist]], [[playwright]] | movement = [[Romanticism]] | notableworks =''Vatan Yahut Silistre''
''Intibah''
''Cezmi''
''Gülnihal'' | nationality = [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] | period = 1871–1888 }} {{History of Turkish literature}} '''Namık Kemal''' (21 December 1840 – 2 December 1888) was an [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] [[Democracy|democrat]]http://file.insightturkey.com/Files/Pdf/insight_turkey_vol_10_no_3_2008_ozler_yildirim.pdf{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=Hd1vAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA288&lpg=PA288&dq=namik+kemal+democrat&source=bl&ots=bmB4M8m9VF&sig=gOe5AnO-xIswY8s_RdiD52AwgUA&hl=nl&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjutK7Z3YzXAhWEthoKHba6DgMQ6AEIYjAI#v=onepage&q=namik%20kemal%20democrat&f=false |title=The History of Islamic Political Thought: From the Prophet to the Present, second edition| last=Black |first=Antony| date=2011 |publisher=Endinburgh University Press|isbn=978-0-7486-3986-1|language=en}}{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=gg7KAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT121&lpg=PT121&dq=namik+kemal+democracy&source=bl&ots=m9LqdEQ8Ps&sig=epRMmnwaf061Z5SFeTeJbjUNKpU&hl=nl&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiz7sK6-a7XAhWBWRoKHYZ7CsMQ6AEIVjAH#v=onepage&q=namik%20kemal%20democracy&f=false |title=Turkey, Identity, Democracy, Politics| last=Kedourie|first=Sylvia| date=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-714-64718-0|language=en}}, writer, intellectual, reformer, journalist, [[playwright]], and [[Political activism|political activist]] who was influential in the formation of the [[Young Ottomans]] and their struggle for governmental reform in the [[Ottoman Empire]] during the late [[Tanzimat]] period, which would lead to the [[First Constitutional Era]] in the Empire in 1876.{{cite book|author1=Gábor Ágoston|author2=Bruce Alan Masters|title=Encyclopedia of the Ottoman Empire|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QjzYdCxumFcC|date=1 January 2009|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1-4381-1025-7|page=417}} Kemal was particularly significant for championing the notions of freedom and fatherland{{cite book|author=Patrick Balfour, 3rd Baron Kinross|authorlink=Patrick Balfour, 3rd Baron Kinross|title=Ottoman Centuries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BhLOtjYtiPoC|date=1 August 1979|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0-688-08093-8|pages=504–505}} in his numerous plays and poems, and his works would have a powerful impact on the establishment of and future reform movements in [[Turkey]], as well as other former Ottoman lands.{{cite book|author1=Gábor Ágoston|author2=Bruce Alan Masters|title=Encyclopedia of the Ottoman Empire|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QjzYdCxumFcC|date=1 January 2009|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1-4381-1025-7|pages=417–418}} He is often regarded as being instrumental in redefining Western concepts like [[Natural and legal rights|natural rights]] and [[Constitution|constitutional government]].{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=UoZRR0gUbJIC&pg=PA20&lpg=PA20&dq=namik+kemal+western+pratice+muslim&source=bl&ots=JYAiXu1hTR&sig=QxXZ6Sl0Qb6AZg0ZX1Uiccuxcq8&hl=nl&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiewMLc6rvXAhXILsAKHXCLAF0Q6AEILzAA#v=onepage&q=namik%20kemal%20western%20pratice%20muslim&f=false |title=Secularism and Muslim Democracy in Turkey| last=Yavuz|first=M. Hakan| date=2009 |publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-88878-3|language=en}} ==Early years== [[File:Namık Kemal-7.2.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Namık Kemal (on the right) with his friend Hikmet]] An [[Albanians|Albanian]] by origin,Metin Heper, ''The State and Kurds in Turkey: The Question of Assimilation'', Springer (2007), p. 60 Namık Kemal was born in [[Tekirdağ]] (then part of the [[Ottoman Empire]], today in [[Turkey]]) on 21 December 1840, to Fatma Zehra and Mustafa Asım Bey, the latter of whom was chief astrologer in the [[Ottoman sultan|Sultan]]’s Palace. Since surnames or family names were not in use during the Ottoman Empire, "Kemal" was not his surname, but part of his first name. During his youth, Kemal traveled throughout the Ottoman Empire, staying in [[Istanbul|Constantinople]], [[Kars]], and [[Sofia]], and studied a number of subjects, including poetry. In 1857, at the age of 17, Kemal worked in the ''Tercüme Odası'' ("The Translation Office") of the government.{{cite book|author1=Stanford J. Shaw|authorlink1=Stanford J. Shaw|author2=Ezel Kural Shaw|authorlink2=Ezel Kural Shaw|title=History of the Ottoman Empire and Modern Turkey|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AIET_7ji7YAC&pg=PA520|volume=2|year=1977|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-29166-8|page=130}} However, as a result of the political nature of his writings, Kemal was forced to leave this job by [[Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire|Grand Vizier]] [[Mehmed Emin Âli Pasha]] and so joined his friend and fellow [[Young Ottomans|Young Ottoman]], [[İbrahim Şinasi]], on his newspaper ''Tasvir-i Efkar'' ("Herald of Ideas"). Kemal worked on ''Tasvir-i Efkar'' until his exile and flight to [[Paris]] in 1867. ==Political career== === Young Ottomans=== The [[Young Ottomans]] were a group of political activists whose members came principally from the young elite of Ottoman society.{{cite book|author1=Stanford J. Shaw|authorlink1=Stanford J. Shaw|author2=Ezel Kural Shaw|authorlink2=Ezel Kural Shaw|title=History of the Ottoman Empire and Modern Turkey|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AIET_7ji7YAC&pg=PA520|volume=2|year=1977|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-29166-8|pages=70–71}}{{cite book|author=Rifaʻat Ali Abou-El-Haj|title=Formation of the Modern State: The Ottoman Empire, Sixteenth to Eighteenth Centuries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cJrVqanlTIUC|year=2005|publisher=Syracuse University Press|isbn=978-0-8156-3085-2|page=79}} The major goal of this group was to institute political reform according to the Western ideas of representative government. After joining the Young Ottomans in 1862, Kemal continually wrote essays on the subjects of political, administrative, social, and foreign policy reform.{{cite book|author1=Gábor Ágoston|author2=Bruce Alan Masters|title=Encyclopedia of the Ottoman Empire|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QjzYdCxumFcC|date=1 January 2009|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1-4381-1025-7|page=418}}{{cite book|author1=Stanford J. Shaw|authorlink1=Stanford J. Shaw|author2=Ezel Kural Shaw|authorlink2=Ezel Kural Shaw|title=History of the Ottoman Empire and Modern Turkey|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AIET_7ji7YAC&pg=PA520|volume=2|year=1977|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-29166-8|page=131}} In 1864, Kemal took over the pro-reform newspaper ''Tasvir-i Efkar'' after its previous owner and Kemal's friend [[İbrahim Şinasi]] was forced into exile. In 1868, after being forced to seek refuge in [[Paris]], Kemal began to handle the publication of the newspaper ''Hürriyet'' ("Liberty"), which also espoused the purpose of the Young Ottomans. Kemal’s papers rapidly became a popular venue for Young Ottomans to express their anti-sultanate and pro-parliamentary sentiments. However, as a result of their outspokenness, many Young Ottomans were, like Kemal, forced to flee the empire and seek refuge in Western Europe. [[Namik Kemal]] admired the constitution of the [[French Third Republic]], he summed up the Young Ottomans' political ideals as "the sovereignty of the nation, the separation of powers, the responsibility of officials, personal freedom, equality, freedom of thought, freedom of press, freedom of association, enjoyment of property, sanctity of the home".{{cite book|last1=Berger|first1=Stefan|last2=Miller|first2=Alexei|title=Nationalizing Empires|date=2015|publisher=Central European University Press|isbn=9633860164|page=447|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=__9fCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA447|accessdate=6 May 2017}}{{cite book|last1=Black|first1=Antony|title=The History of Islamic Political Thought: From the Prophet to the Present|date=2011|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|isbn=0748688781|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hd1vAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA286|accessdate=6 May 2017}}Hanioğlu, M. Şükrü (2008). ''A Brief History of the Late Ottoman Empire'', Princeton University Press. {{ISBN|0-691-14617-9}}. p. 104. ==Ideology and exile== [[File:Namık Kemal-2.jpg|thumb|185px|right|An old photograph of Namık Kemal]] Namık Kemal was heavily influenced by Western conceptions of the relationship between the government and the people. As such, he and his compatriots spoke out against the movement to centralize the government being undertaken by Sultan [[Abdülaziz]] (ruled 1861–1876), and his advisors [[Mehmed Emin Âli Pasha]] and [[Mehmed Fuad Pasha]].{{cite book|author1=Gábor Ágoston|author2=Bruce Alan Masters|title=Encyclopedia of the Ottoman Empire|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QjzYdCxumFcC|date=1 January 2009|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1-4381-1025-7|page=5}} As a result of his criticism of the government, Namık Kemal was exiled from the [[Ottoman Empire]] in 1867 and fled to [[Paris]], where many other exiled [[Young Ottomans]] had found refuge.{{cite book|author=Patrick Balfour, 3rd Baron Kinross|authorlink=Patrick Balfour, 3rd Baron Kinross|title=Ottoman Centuries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BhLOtjYtiPoC|date=1 August 1979|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0-688-08093-8|page=506}} In 1869 or 1870, Kemal was allowed to return to [[Istanbul|Constantinople]] and proceeded to write for a number of Young Ottoman-run newspapers, and eventually published one of his own, ''Ibret'' ("Admonition"), in which he addressed more intellectual, social, and national subjects. In addition, it was after his return to [[Istanbul|Constantinople]] that Kemal wrote his most significant and influential work: the play ''Vatan Yahut Silistre'', or ''Silistra'', which translates to "Fatherland." The play tells the story of an [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] soldier whose loyalty to his nation, and not his religion or allegiance to the [[Sultan of the Ottoman Empire|Sultan]], motivates him to defend the town of [[Silistra]], [[Bulgaria]] from the [[Russian Empire|Russians]] during the [[Crimean War]].{{cite book|author=Patrick Balfour, 3rd Baron Kinross|authorlink=Patrick Balfour, 3rd Baron Kinross|title=Ottoman Centuries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BhLOtjYtiPoC|date=1 August 1979|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0-688-08093-8|page=507}} The impact these nationalist sentiments, unheard of in the [[Ottoman Empire]] prior to Kemal, had on the [[Turkish people]] was so profound that Kemal’s newspaper, ''Ibret'', was shut down, and Kemal himself was banished from the Empire for the second time. During this second exile, Kemal took refuge in [[Cyprus]], in a building known as the [[Namık Kemal Dungeon]] in [[Famagusta]], where he remained for three years. ===Later career=== [[File:Namik kemal2.jpg|thumb|185px|Namık Kemal was one of the leading figures in creating a national identity]] Like many [[Young Ottomans]], Namık Kemal supported [[Murad V]]’s ascension to the throne after the abdication of [[Abdülaziz]] in 1876.{{cite book|author=Patrick Balfour, 3rd Baron Kinross|authorlink=Patrick Balfour, 3rd Baron Kinross|title=Ottoman Centuries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BhLOtjYtiPoC|date=1 August 1979|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0-688-08093-8|page=514}} However, their hope that Murad would institute the reforms they desired was dashed, for it rapidly became apparent that he was not suited for rule; his weak nerves and alcoholism leading to his abdication after only three months.{{cite book|author1=Gábor Ágoston|author2=Bruce Alan Masters|title=Encyclopedia of the Ottoman Empire|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QjzYdCxumFcC|date=1 January 2009|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1-4381-1025-7|page=404}} Namık Kemal protested against [[Murad V|Murad]]’s deposition, and continued to support Murad’s Western political perspectives, but ultimately, his pleas failed to have any effect and [[Murad V]] stepped down in 1876.{{cite book|author=Patrick Balfour, 3rd Baron Kinross|authorlink=Patrick Balfour, 3rd Baron Kinross|title=Ottoman Centuries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BhLOtjYtiPoC|date=1 August 1979|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0-688-08093-8|page=515}} Despite Murad’s abdication, the first Ottoman Parliament, the [[General Assembly of the Ottoman Empire]], was established in 1876, largely as a result of pressure from the [[Young Ottomans]], as well as [[Midhat Pasha]]’s political influence.{{cite book|author1=Stanford J. Shaw|authorlink1=Stanford J. Shaw|author2=Ezel Kural Shaw|authorlink2=Ezel Kural Shaw|title=History of the Ottoman Empire and Modern Turkey|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AIET_7ji7YAC&pg=PA520|volume=2|year=1977|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-29166-8|pages=181–182}} However, while, at first, [[Abdul Hamid II]], the sultan who succeeded [[Murad V]], was willing to allow Parliament to function, he quickly decided that it was easier for him to enact reform by seizing autocratic powers instead of waiting for the approval of elected officials.{{cite book|author1=Stanford J. Shaw|authorlink1=Stanford J. Shaw|author2=Ezel Kural Shaw|authorlink2=Ezel Kural Shaw|title=History of the Ottoman Empire and Modern Turkey|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AIET_7ji7YAC&pg=PA520|volume=2|year=1977|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-29166-8|page=212}} In order to successfully implement his autocratic rule, Abdul Hamid II exiled many [[Young Ottomans]], including Namık Kemal, who were critical of his decision to disregard the Parliament.{{cite book|author=Patrick Balfour, 3rd Baron Kinross|authorlink=Patrick Balfour, 3rd Baron Kinross|title=Ottoman Centuries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BhLOtjYtiPoC|date=1 August 1979|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0-688-08093-8|page=530}} Thus, for the third time, Kemal was removed from [[Istanbul|Constantinople]] by being forced into an administrative position in [[Chios]], where he would die in 1888.{{cite book|author1=Stanford J. Shaw|authorlink1=Stanford J. Shaw|author2=Ezel Kural Shaw|authorlink2=Ezel Kural Shaw|title=History of the Ottoman Empire and Modern Turkey|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AIET_7ji7YAC&pg=PA520|volume=2|year=1977|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-29166-8|pages=212–213}} ==Legacy== Namık Kemal had an enormous influence on the formation of a [[Turkish nationalism|Turkish national identity]]. Kemal’s focus on national loyalty, rather than loyalty to a monarch, influenced, as it was, by Western European ideals of self-government, contributed not only to the spread of democracy during the early 20th century, but also to the formation of the modern [[Turkey|Republic of Turkey]] after the dissolution of the [[Ottoman Empire]].{{cite book|author1=Stanford J. Shaw|authorlink1=Stanford J. {{hatnote|"Pornification" redirects here.}} {{For2|"Porno chic" or "The Golden Age of Porn"|[[Golden Age of Porn]]}} '''Pornographication''' or '''pornification''', sometimes referred to as '''[[raunch]] culture''', denotes the intrusion of the style and contents of the [[sex industry]] into mainstream culture (music, television, [[Hollywood movie]]s) and the [[sexualisation]] of [[Western culture]].<ref name="Attwood">{{citation | last = McNair | first = Brian | contribution = From [[porno-chic]] to porno-fear: the return of the repressed (Abstract) |editor-last=Attwood|editor-first=Feona|title=Mainstreaming Sex: The Sexualisation of Western Culture|url=http://strathprints.strath.ac.uk/18574/ |year=2009|publisher=IB Taurus|location=London|isbn=978-1-84511-827-3 |pages=110–130 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Pornographication, particularly sexualising the images of women, is said to demonstrate "how [[patriarchal]] power operates in the field of [[gender]] representation".<ref>{{citation|last=Woodward|first=Kath|contribution = Gendered bodies: gendered representations | editor-last = Woodward | editor-first = Kath |title=The Short Guide to Gender|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JtmaeNvWodUC&pg=PA85&lpg=PA85&dq=pornogrification&source=bl&hl=en |year=2011|publisher=The Policy Press, University of Bristol|isbn=978-1-84742-763-2 |page=85 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> In ''Women in Popular Culture'', Marion Meyers argues that the portrayal of women in modern society is primarily influenced by "the mainstreaming of [[pornography]] and its resultant hypersexualization of women and girls, and the [[commodification]] of those images for a global market".<ref>{{cite book|last=Meyers|first=Marian|title=Women in Popular Culture: Representation and Meaning|url=http://www.hamptonpress.com/Merchant2/merchant.mvc?Screen=PROD&Product_Code=1-57273-828-6&Category_Code=Q208 |date=May 2008|publisher=Hampton Press}}</ref>
The phenomenon has been discussed by authors such as Marian Meyers and Kath Woodward. Pornographication also features in discussions of [[post-feminism]] by [[Ariel Levy (journalist)|Ariel Levy]],<ref>{{cite book | last = Levy | first = Ariel | author-link = Ariel Levy (journalist) | title = [[Female Chauvinist Pigs|Female chauvinist pigs: women and the rise of raunch culture]] | publisher = Free Press | location = New York | year = 2006 | isbn = 9780743284288 }}</ref> [[Natasha Walter]],<ref>{{cite book | last = Walter | first = Natasha | author-link = Natasha Walter | title = Living dolls: the return of sexism | publisher = Virago | location = London | year = 2010 | isbn = 9781844084845 }}</ref> Feona Attwood, and Brian McNair.<ref name="Attwood"/><ref>{{cite book | last = McNair | first = Brian | title = Porno? Chic!: how pornography changed the world and made it a better place | publisher = Routledge | location = Abingdon, Oxon New York, NY | year = 2013 | isbn = 9780203134153 }}</ref>
== History == Pornography and the modern sex culture has been around for many decades, but has its roots in the Greek word "''porni'', which means prostitute and ''graphein'', which means to write. It is shown throughout various global cultures. In ancient Greece and Rome, there was many sexually charged images on the walls. When the printing press was invented, it was much easier to distribute information to the masses, which is how the first versions of [[erotica]] came about. What most people think about Western pornography and the sex culture started with the [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] of the 18th century. Many more people had access to pornographic material during the Enlightenment, and in England books such as ''Fanny Hill; or, Memoirs of a Woman of Pleasure''<ref>{{cite book | last = Cleland | first = John | author-link = John Cleland | title = Fanny Hill, or, Memoirs of a woman of pleasure | publisher = Penguin Books | location = Harmondsworth, Middlesex, England New York, N.Y., U.S.A | year = 1985 | isbn = 9780140432497 }}</ref> had commercial success as one of the earliest forms of erotica. During this time, people started thinking more freely, so [[pornography]] could challenge the norms of the time, as with [[Marquis de Sade]]'s book ''[[Justine (de Sade novel)|Justine]].''<ref>{{cite book | last = de Sade | first = Marquis | author-link = Marquis de Sade | others = Pieralessandro Casavini (translator) | title = Les Infortunes de la Vertu | trans-title = [[Justine (de Sade novel)|Justine, or The Misfortunes of Virtue]] | language = French | publisher = Olympia Press | location = Paris | year = 1961 | origyear = 1791 | oclc = 50373239 }}</ref> While most pornographic images before the 19th century were images or books, when the [[motion picture]] was invented, it created a whole new medium for sexual imagery. At the start of the 1920s, it became popular throughout the West.

== Effects of media == {{Multiple image | direction = vertical | footer = [[Jamie Dornan]] and [[Dakota Johnson]] were cast in the lead roles in the [[BDSM]] inspired movie, [[Fifty Shades of Grey (film)|Fifty Shades of Grey]]. | image1 =Jamie_Dornan_January_2013.jpg<!--Jamie Dornan 2014.jpg--> | width1 = 125 | image2 = Dakota Johnson 2014 (cropped).jpg | width2 = 121 }} === Movies === In [[slasher movie]]s, sex and violence are often coupled together. In famous [[horror film]]s such as ''[[Friday the 13th]]'', women are portrayed as weak and often are victims. Because of repeated viewing of these movies, people may become [[Desensitization (psychology)|desensitized]], and especially with males, could be prone to "be less disturbed by scenes of extreme violence and degradation directed at women". Men, after repeated exposure to violent films, were less likely to feel empathy and remorse.<ref>{{cite web | title = Sexual assault and the media | url = http://www.stopvaw.org/sexual_assault_and_the_media | website = stopvaw.org | publisher = Stop Violence Against Women, the Advocates for Human Rights | date = 13 July 2009 | access-date = 5 December 2016 }}</ref> Men could think that violence towards women is normal, which therefore leads to more [[sexual violence]] towards women.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Sapolsky | first1 = Barry | last2 = Molitor | first2 = Fred | last3 = Luque | first3 = Sarah | title = Sex and violence in slasher films: re-examining the assumptions | journal = [[Journalism and Mass Communication Quarterly]] | volume = 80 | issue = 1 | pages = 26–38 | publisher = [[SAGE Publications|Sage]] | doi = 10.1177/107769900308000103 | date = March 2003 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1177/107769900308000103 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> These movies are just one example of how sexuality is translated to men and women, explicitly showing men as dominant and powerful, and women as weak.
=== Television === Teens who were exposed to highly sexual content on TV were more likely to "act older" than their age. If what was being shown on TV was educational, it could yield a positive result on teenagers. For example, on one specific episode of ''Friends'', which had nearly 2 million viewers at the time, one of the characters had gotten pregnant even after using [[contraception]]. After the episode, teens were actually more likely to engage in [[Safe sex|safer sexual activity]], and as much as 65% remembered what was in that episode.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Collins | first1 = Rebecca L. | last2 = Elliott | first2 = Marc N. | last3 = Berry | first3 = Sandra H. | last4 = Kanouse | first4 = David E. | last5 = Kunkel | first5 = Dale | last6 = Hunter | first6 = Sarah B. | last7 = Miu | first7 = Angela | title = Does watching sex on television influence teens’ sexual activity? | url = http://www.rand.org/pubs/research_briefs/RB9068.html | publisher = [[RAND Corporation]] | access-date = 5 December 2016 }}</ref>
=== Books === Literature which people read for sexual satisfaction is one of the earliest forms of media portraying sexuality. Now, there are various websites to satisfy most people's varied sexual preferences and tastes. As [[erotica]] was a form of social protest against the values of the culture at the time, as was with the famous book ''[[The Romance of Lust]]'', written as a few volumes between 1873–1876. Described in the book are [[homosexuality]], [[incest]], and other socially unacceptable concepts. The values of the [[Victorian era]] perpetuated purity and innocence. So this book offered a new perspective.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Anonymous|title=The Romance Of Lust|date=1873–1876|publisher=Grove Green|location=United Kingdom|edition=1892|url=http://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/30254/pg30254-images.html | oclc = 760964009}}</ref> In recent years, erotica has become the new norm, and is extremely popular. The most recent commercial success was ''[[Fifty Shades Of Grey]]'', describing in detail scenes of [[sadomasochism]] and other forms of kink.<ref>{{cite book | last = James | first = E.L. | author-link = E. L. James | title = Fifty shades of Grey | publisher = Vintage Books | location = New York | year = 2012 | isbn = 9780872723269 }}</ref> It sold over "31 million worldwide", and has been adapted into a film starring [[Dakota Johnson]] and [[Jamie Dornan]].<ref>{{cite news | last = Grinberg | first = Emanuella | title = Explaining ''Fifty Shades'' wild success | url = http://www.cnn.com/2012/07/13/living/fifty-shades-buzz-50-shades-success/ | work = [[CNN]] | date = 13 July 2012 }}</ref>
=== Magazines === Magazines often portray sex in a very indirect way. As seen in [[advertisements]] throughout, sex is portrayed without anyone needing to say a word. However, in a lot of ways, this can be devastating to people's [[Psyche (psychology)|psyche]]s, especially women. Magazines feature women barely clothed in provocative positions, which can communicate that women are not good enough. One of the more unlikely effects is it affecting dieting patterns.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Thomsen | first1 = Steven R. | last2 = Weber | first2 = Michelle M. | last3 = Brown | first3 = Lora Beth | title = The relationship between reading beauty and fashion magazines and the use of pathogenic dieting methods among adolescent females | journal = Adolescence | volume = 37 | issue = 145 | pages = 1–18 | publisher = Libra Publishers | date = Spring 2002 | pmid = 12003283 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} Access also available via [https://www.thefreelibrary.com/The+relationship+between+reading+beauty+and+fashion+magazines+and+the...-a086056749 The Free Library.]</ref>
==Sociological theories== In order to understand how sex culture is so prevalent, we need to look at [[human sexuality]] as a whole and why people gravitate towards such mediums as described above.
===Structuralism=== [[Structuralism]] is commonly defined as "analyzing a specific field as a complex system of interrelated parts".<ref>{{cite web | last = Mastin | first = Luke | title = Structuralism | url = http://www.philosophybasics.com/movements_structuralism.html | website = philosophybasics.com | publisher = The Basics of Philosophy }}</ref> This term used in sociology was popularized with Michel Foucault, in France where most of the early research took place on it. Sociologists who look at sexuality focus on the idea of social institutions, such as the family, law, and the economy. The economy requires money to go in and out of the system. People could say sexual relationships are a social institution. Due to the Western acceptance of [[Judeo-Christianity]], incest is rarely represented in the media. The idea of the family is so powerful and strong that dating someone or having relations with a member of one's family is highly taboo. A structuralist would argue that sex culture is an offshoot of these institutions. When it comes to pornography, it is another way of income and is an offshoot of the economy and the highly capitalistic ideas of the West.<ref>{{cite book | last = Foucault | first = Michel | author-link = Michel Foucault | title = The history of sexuality: volume 1, the will to knowledge | date = 1998 | publisher = Penguin | location = London | oclc = 929056897}}</ref> This is also expressed in how the family affects teenagers who view certain types of media, and those who are marginalized may be more susceptible to the negative impacts of sexuality.
=== Symbolic interactionism === [[Symbolic interactionism]] was first coined by [[George Herbert Mead]], who came up with this school of sociological thought in the 1930s. Its premise is primarily based on "objects acquire meaning, thus becoming symbols, through communication". One of his most famous books ''Mind, Self And Society'' is famous for describing this theory in depth. Here, he pinpoints the [[self]] as an object and other create meaning around it. At the same time, we change the self depending on how we perceive other's ideas of our selves.<ref>{{cite book | last = Mead | first = George Herbert | author-link = George Herbert Mead | editor-last = Morris | editor-first = Charles W. | editor-link = Charles W. Morris | title = Mind, self, and society from the standpoint of a social behaviorist | publisher = University of Chicago Press | location = Chicago, Illinois | year = 1962 | isbn = 9780226516684 }}</ref> So in studying something like sexuality or acts related to sex, a sociologist under this perspective could look at pornography and the messages it communicates, or look at magazines and the messages they send to people. One graphic example provided is the "power" symbol communicated in pornography. In pornography, men are implied to be powerful and dominant, whereas women are not. This is especially true in violent pornography, where the person watching feels like they have a complete sense of control over the content, where women are depicted as enjoying it, so that communicates that it may be okay to be violent towards women.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Gossett | first1 = Jennifer Lynn | last2 = Byrne | first2 = Sarah | title = "Click Here": a content analysis of internet rape sites | journal = [[Gender & Society]] | volume = 16 | issue = 5 | pages = 689–709 | publisher = [[SAGE Publications|Sage]] | doi = 10.1177/089124302236992 | date = October 2002 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1177/089124302236992 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
=== Scripting theory === With [[Sexual script theory|scripting theory]], it "is the result of elaborate prior learning that teaches us an etiquette of sexual behavior". It is all about [[Social learning theory|social learning]] and scripting theory states that everything we see and do sexually in our culture is influenced by a set of social scripts that are conditioned into people. These provide details and instructions to guide us into how people choose partners and therefore, who they find attractive or desirable. As mentioned before, magazines can indirectly send this message. Since what is shown primarily is a woman's appearance, so women instinctively realize they need to appear a certain way for a mate. It is a socially learned behavior that happens from repeated exposure.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Shibley-Hyde | first1 = Janet | last2 = DeLamater | first2 = John | title = Understanding human sexuality | publisher = McGraw-Hill | location = New York | year = 2003 | isbn = 9780072494716 | edition = 8th |authorlink1=Janet Shibley Hyde|authorlink2= John DeLamater}}</ref>

'''Public interest design''' is a human-centered<ref>[http://www.hcdconnect.org/methods HCD Connect Methods]</ref> and participatory design practice<ref name=Cary>{{cite web|last=Cary|first=John|title=Infographic: Public Interest Design|url=http://www.publicinterestdesign.org/infographic/|publisher=PublicInterestDesign.org|accessdate=23 October 2012}}</ref> that places emphasis on the “[[triple bottom line]]” of [[sustainable design]] that includes ecological, economic, and social issues and on designing products, structures, and systems that address issues such as [[economic development]] and the preservation of the environment.
Starting in the late 1990s, several books, convenings, and exhibitions have generated new momentum and investment in public interest design. Since then, public interest design—frequently described as a movement or field—has gained public recognition.<ref>{{cite news|last=Cary|first=John|title=Dignifying Design|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/07/opinion/sunday/dignifying-design.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=23 October 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=October 6, 2012|author2=Courtney E. Martin}}</ref>
==History== Public interest design grew out of the community design movement, which got its start in 1968 after American [[civil rights]] leader [[Whitney Young]] issued a challenge to attendees of the American Institute of Architects (AIA) national convention:<ref>{{cite book|last=Leavitt|first=Jacqueline|title=From the Studio to the Streets: Service Learning in Planning and Architecture|year=2006|publisher=Stylus Publishing|location=Sterling, VA|isbn=978-1563771002|pages=103|authorlink=Multiplying Knowledge: Service-Learning x Activism = Community Scholars|author2=Kara Hoffernan |editor=Mary C. Hardin}}</ref>
". . . ''you are not a profession that has distinguished itself by your social and civic contributions to the cause of civil rights, and I am sure this does not come to you as any shock. You are most distinguished by your thunderous silence and your complete irrelevance''.<ref>[http://www.designingactivism.com/2011/12/31/whitney-young-1968-speech-to-the-aia Whitney Young 1968 Speech to the AIA]</ref>"
The response to Young’s challenge was the establishment of community design centers (CDCs) across the United States.<ref>[http://www.designcoalition.org/aboutus/our%20roots.htm Design Coalition, "Our Roots"]</ref> CDCs, which were often established with the support of area universities,<ref name=Pearson>{{cite book|last=Pearson|first=Jason|title=University-Community Design Partnerships: Innovations in Practice|year=2002|publisher=Princeton Architectural Press|location=New York, New York|isbn=1-56898-379-4|pages=6–7|url=http://www.nea.gov/pub/UnivCommDesign.pdf|editor=Mark Robbins|accessdate=23 October 2012}}</ref> provided a variety of design services – such as affordable housing - within their own neighborhoods.
In architecture schools, “design/build programs” provided outreach to meet local design needs, particularly in low-income and underserved areas.<ref name=Pearson/> One of the earliest design/build programs was [[Yale University]]’s Vlock Building Project. The project, which was initiated by students at Yale University School of Architecture in 1967, requires graduate students to design and build low-income housing.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hill|first=David|title=The New Frontier in Education|url=http://archrecord.construction.com/news/2012/03/The-New-Frontier-Education.asp|publisher=Architectural Record|accessdate=23 October 2012|date=March 2012}}</ref>
One of the most publicized programs is the [[Auburn University]] [[Rural Studio]] design/build program, which was founded in 1993.<ref name=Cary/><ref>{{cite web|last=Clemence|first=Sara|title=Avant-Garde in Alabama|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304356604577342370002244732|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=23 October 2012|date=April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Bostwick|first=William|title="Citizen Architect": The Humble Origins of Socially-Responsible Design|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/1585096/citizen-architect-humble-origins-socially-responsible-design|publisher=Fast Company|accessdate=23 October 2012}}</ref> The Rural Studio’s first project, Bryant House, was completed in 1994 for $16,500.<ref>{{cite web|title=Samuel Mockbee and the Rural Studio: Community Architecture|url=http://www.nbm.org/exhibitions-collections/exhibitions/samuel-mockbee.html|publisher=National Building Museum|accessdate=23 October 2012}}</ref>
==Public Interest Design from the 1990s – Present== Interest in public interest design – particularly socially responsible architecture – began to grow during the 1990s and continued into the first decade of the new millennium. Conferences, books, and exhibitions began to showcase the design work being done beyond the community design centers,<ref name=Cary /> which had greatly decreased in numbers since their peak in the seventies.<ref name=Pearson/>
[[Non-profit]] organizations – including [[Architecture for Humanity]], BaSiC Initiative, Design Corps, [[Public Architecture]], Project H, Project Locus, and MASS Design Group – began to provide design services that served a larger segment of the population than had been served by traditional design professions.<ref name=Cary/><ref>{{cite web|last=Hughes|first=C.J.|title=Does "Doing Good" Pay the Bills?|url=http://archrecord.construction.com/practice/Community-Service/2012/03/perspective-practice/Humanitarian-Work.asp|publisher=Architectural Record|accessdate=23 October 2012|date=March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Allweil|first1=Yael|title=The House of Dance and Feathers Mardi Gras Indian Museum-New Orleans, LA by Project Locus: Patrick Rhodes, Executive Director [EDRA/Places Awards 2007--Design].|journal=Places|date=2007|volume=19|issue=3}}</ref>
Many public interest design organizations also provide training and [[service-learning]] programs for architecture students and graduates. In 1999, the Enterprise Rose Architectural Fellowship was established,<ref name=Cary/> giving young architects the opportunity to work on three-year-long design and community development projects in low-income communities.<ref>[http://www.enterprisecommunity.com/solutions-and-innovation/design-leadership/rose-architectural-fellowship/about-the-fellowship Enterprise Community website, "About the Fellowship"]</ref>
Two of the earliest formal public interest design programs include the Gulf Coast Community Design Studio at Mississippi State University<ref name=Cary>{{cite web|last=Cary|first=John|title=Chronology of the Public Interest Design Field|url=http://www.publicinterestdesign.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/Public-Interest-Design-Chronology-120601.pdf|accessdate=23 October 2012|coauthors=PublicInterestDesign.org, University of Minnesota College of Design, Tandus Flooring}}</ref> and the Public Interest Design Summer Program at the [[University of Texas]]<ref name=Cary/> .<ref>[http://soa.utexas.edu/csd/PID/overview.html Overview of Public Interest Design program, University of Texas School of Architecture] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120416152806/http://www.soa.utexas.edu/csd/PID/overview.html |date=2012-04-16 }}</ref> In February 2015, Portland State University launched the first graduate certificate program in Public Interest Design in the United States.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pdx.edu/the-arts/recent-and-upcoming/cpid-launches-graduate-certificate-in-public-interest-design |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-02-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150218044206/http://www.pdx.edu/the-arts/recent-and-upcoming/cpid-launches-graduate-certificate-in-public-interest-design |archivedate=2015-02-18 |df= }}</ref>
The first professional-level training was conducted in July 2011 by the Public Interest Design Institute (PIDI) and held at the [[Harvard]] Graduate School of Design.<ref>[http://www.publicinterestdesign.com/harvard-school-of-design%20 Harvard School of Design course description]</ref>
Also in 2011, a survey of [[American Institute of Architects]] (AIA), 77% of AIA members agreed that the mission of the professional practice of public interest design could be defined as the belief that every person should be able to live in a socially, economically, and environmentally healthy community.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bell|first=Bryan|title=Public Interest Design Takes Shape|url=http://www.metropolismag.com/pov/20120917/public-interest-design-takes-shape|publisher=Metropolismag.com|accessdate=23 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Bell|first=Bryan|author2=Roberta Feldman |author3=Sergio Palleroni |author4=Davide Perkes |title=2011 Latrobe Prize Progress Report: Public Interest Practices in Architecture|date=31 December 2011|url=http://www.aia.org/aiaucmp/groups/aia/documents/pdf/aiab094604.pdf|accessdate=23 October 2012}}</ref>
==Publications, Conferences, and Exhibits== Several books have been published that showcase a variety of public interest design projects and practitioners:
* ''Good Neighbors, Affordable Family Housing." Tom Jones, William Pettus, and Michael Pyatok, 1997 ({{ISBN|978-0070329133}})<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Good-Neighbors-Affordable-Family-Housing/dp/0070329133/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1351093676&sr=8-2&keywords=good+neighbors%2C+affordable+family+housing ''Good Neighbors, Affordable Family Housing'' book description on Amazon.com]</ref> * ''Learning by Building: Design and Construction in Architectural Education." William J. Carpenter, 1997 ({{ISBN|978-0471287933}})<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Learning-Building-Construction-Architectural-Education/dp/0471287938/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1351094037&sr=1-1&keywords=learning+by+building ''Learning by Building: Design and Construction in Architectural Education'' book description on Amazon.com]</ref> * ''Good Deeds, Good Design: Community Service through Architecture." Bryan Bell, 2003 ({{ISBN|978-1568983912}})<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Good-Deeds-Design-Community-Architecture/dp/1568983913/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1351094180&sr=1-2&keywords=good+deeds%2C+good+design ''Good Deeds, Good Design: Community Service through Architecture'' book description on Amazon.com]</ref> * ''Design Like You Give a Damn: Architectural Responses to Humanitarian Crises''. Kate Stohr and Cameron Sinclair, ed., 2006 ({{ISBN|978-1933045252}})<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Design-Like-Give-Damn-Architectural/dp/1933045256/ref=pd_sim_b_2 ''Design Like You Give a Damn: Architectural Responses to Humanitarian Crises'' book description on Amazon.com]</ref> * ''Expanding Architecture, Design as Activism." Bryan Bell and Katie Wakeford, ed., 2008 ({{ISBN|978-1933045788}})<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Expanding-Architecture-Design-as-Activism/dp/1933045787/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1351094399&sr=1-1&keywords=expanding+architecture ''Expanding Architecture, Design as Activism'' book description on Amazon.com]</ref> * ''Design Revolution: 100 Products that Empower People.'' Emily Pilloton, 2009 ({{ISBN|978-1933045955}})<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Design-Revolution-Products-Empower-People/dp/1933045957/ref=pd_sim_b_9 ''Design Revolution: 100 Products that Empower People'' book description on Amazon.com]</ref> * ''The Power of Pro Bono: 40 Stories about Design for the Public Good by Architects and Their Clients.'' John Cary, 2010 ({{ISBN|978-1935202189}})<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Power-Pro-Bono-John-Cary/dp/1935202189/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1351094642&sr=1-1&keywords=power+of+pro+bono ''The Power of Pro Bono'' book description on Amazon.com]</ref> * ''Design Like You Give a Damn 2: Building Change from the Ground Up." Kate Stohr and Cameron Sinclair, ed., 2012 ({{ISBN|978-0810997028}})<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Design-Like-You-Give-Damn/dp/0810997029 ''Design Like You Give a Damn 2: Building Change from the Ground Up'' book description on Amazon.com]</ref>
The annual Structures for Inclusion conference showcases public interest design projects from around the world. The first conference, which was held in 2000, was called “Design for the 98% Without Architects."<ref name=Cary/> Speaking at the conference, Rural Studio co-founder [[Samuel Mockbee]] challenged attendees to serve a greater segment of the population: “I believe most of us would agree that American architecture today exists primarily within a thin band of elite social and economic conditions<ref name=Bell>{{cite book|last=Bell|first=Bryan|title=Good Deeds, Good Design: Community Service Through Architecture|year=2003|publisher=Princeton Architectural Press|location=New York, New York|isbn=978-1568983912|pages=156}}</ref>...in creating architecture, and ultimately community, it should make no difference which economic or social type is served, as long as the status quo of the actual world is transformed by an imagination that creates a proper harmony for both the affluent and the disadvantaged.<ref name=Bell/>"
In 2007, the [[Cooper Hewitt National Design Museum]] held an exhibition, titled “Design for the Other 90%,” curated by Cynthia Smith. Following the success of this exhibit, Smith developed the "Design Other 90" initiative into an ongoing series, the second of which was titled “Design for the Other 90%: CITIES”<ref>[http://www.cooperhewitt.org/exhibitions/design-other-90-cities Design for the Other 90%: CITIES] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121016121902/http://www.cooperhewitt.org/exhibitions/design-other-90-cities |date=2012-10-16 }}</ref> (2011), held at the [[United Nations]] headquarters. In 2010, Andres Lipek of the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in New York curated an exhibit, called “Small Scale, Big Change: New Architectures of Social Engagement.<ref>[http://www.moma.org/interactives/exhibitions/2010/smallscalebigchange/ MoMA Exhibition: "Small Scale, Big Change: New Architectures of Social Engagement"]</ref>”<ref name=Cary/>
==Professional Networks== One of the oldest professional networks related to public interest design is the professional organization is the Association for Community Design (ACD), which was founded in 1977.<ref name=Cary/><ref>[http://www.communitydesign.org/about Association for Community Design website, "About" page]</ref>{{non primary source needed}}
In 2005, adopting a term coined by architect Kimberly Dowdell, the Social Economic Environmental Design (SEED) Network was co-founded by a group of community design leaders,<ref name=Cary/> during a meeting hosted by the Loeb Fellowship at the Harvard Graduate School of Design. The SEED Network established a common set of five principles and criteria for practitioners of public interest design. An evaluation tool called the SEED Evaluator is available to assist designers and practitioners in developing projects that align with SEED Network goals and criteria.{{cn|date=January 2018}}
In 2006, the Open Architecture Network was launched by [[Architecture for Humanity]] in conjunction with co-founder [[Cameron Sinclair]]'s TED Wish.<ref>[http://www.ted.com/talks/cameron_sinclair_on_open_source_architecture.html Cameron Sinclair's TED Prize talk and wish for the Open Architecture Network]</ref>{{non primary source needed}} Taking on the name Worldchanging in 2011, the network is an open-source community dedicated to improving living conditions through innovative and sustainable design. Designers of all persuasions can share ideas, designs and plans as well as collaborate and manage projects. while protecting their intellectual property rights using the [[Creative Commons]] "some rights reserved" licensing system.
In 2007, DESIGN 21: Social Design Network, an online platform built in partnership with UNESCO, was launched.
In 2011, the Design Other 90 Network was launched by the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, in conjunction with its Design with the Other 90%: CITIES exhibition.
In 2012, IDEO.org, with the support of The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, launched HCD Connect, a network for social sector leaders committed to human-centered design. In this context, human-centered design begins with the end-user of a product, place, or system — taking into account their needs, behaviors and desires. The fast-growing professional network of 15,000 builds on "The Human-Centered Design Toolkit,"<ref>[http://www.ideo.com/work/human-centered-design-toolkit/ The Human-Centered Design Toolkit from IDEO]</ref>{{non-primary source needed|date=January 2018}} which was designed specifically for people, nonprofits, and social enterprises that work with low-income communities throughout the world. People using the HCD Toolkit or human-centered design in the social sector now have a place to share their experiences, ask questions, and connect with others working in similar areas or on similar challenges.
==See also== {{Portal|Architecture|Sustainable development}} * [[Design/Build]] * [[Healthy community design]] * [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design]] * [[Sustainable architecture]] * [[Sustainable Design]]
==References==
<references />

[[File:Intercontinental sf popo sign.jpg|thumb|Public Open Space sign in San Francisco.]]
'''Public open space''' is often referred to by [[urban planner]]s and [[landscape architect]]s by the acronym 'POS'. Varied interpretations of the term are possible.
'Public' can mean: * owned by a national or local government body * owned by 'public' body (e.g. a not-for-profit organization) and held in trust for the public * owned by a private individual or organization but made available for public use or available public access, see [[privately owned public space]] (POPS)
'Open' can mean: * open for public access * open for public recreation * outdoors, i.e. not a space within a building * vegetated
Depending on which of these definitions are adopted, any of the following could be called Public Open Space:
* a [[public park]] * a [[town square]] * a [[greenway (landscape)|greenway]] which is open to the public but runs through farmland or a forest * a public [[highway]] * a [[private road]] with public access
==See also== *[[Environmental good]] *[[Landscape architecture]] *[[Landscape planning]] *[[Public good]] *[[Public space]]
==External links== * [http://www.pps.org/ Project for Public Space] – information on creating and sustaining public places * [http://www.cabespace.org.uk CABEspace] – a government agency for good public park design in England * [http://www.uli.org/ Urban Land Institute] – information on the use of land to enhance the environment.
